title: Tuesday, 20th June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Hi there, welcome to Markets Live. It's Varey-And-Jenkins-Have-Been-Charged-by-The-SFO-day.

BE11:06am

If you've missed the news, here's the news.

BE11:06am

11:06 am
BE11:06am

BE11:06am

BE11:06am

11:06 am
BE11:07am

BE11:07am

BE11:07am

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Story here: https://www.ft.com...-9fed-c19e2700005f

BE11:07am

Varley backgrounder here: https://www.ft.com...-80b6-9bfa4c1f83d2

BE11:08am

And another one on Jenkins here (which perhaps uniquely to newspaper coverage is missing photos of both his ex wife and his ex girlfriend): https://www.ft.com...-80b6-9bfa4c1f83d2 ....... (He "intends to vigorously defend against these charges")

11:08 am
BE11:08am

BTW, important note.

BE11:08am

Now we have folk charged can we keep the comments on the right side of legal? I don't want to be in contempt of court, and I imagine neither do you.

BE11:09am

For example, we can't have any speculation about why other prominent Barclays executives aren't included.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

So let's stick to generalities.

BE11:09am

We talked here in reference to Petrofac about whether the SFO's been emboldened by being existentially threatened.

BE11:09am

This is turbo-Petrofac.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

It is the culmination of a five-year Treasury-backed special investigation, of course, but it might also be seen as proof of the SFO's efficacy. They've a lot riding on this one.

BE11:10am

Also, though .........

BE11:10am

The outcome's going to cast new light on the FCA.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

You'll remember the FCA slapped Barclays with a £50m penalty back in 2013 for failing to disclose its relationships with Qatari investors, and that Barclays challenged both the conclusion and the fine.

BE11:11am

That case was then frozen when the SFO opened its casebook.

BE11:11am

Which helps explain this slightly defensive statement out of the FCA this morning.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

"We are pleased that this matter, which led to the stay of our own case, is now in the public domain. We welcome a fair and transparent hearing on the basis of the charges set out today by the SFO. We work closely with the SFO across a range of matters, in pursuit of our distinct objectives. ”

BE11:11am

Hm. A reminder that the FCA has powers of criminal prosecution and an annual budget (2016-17) of £502.9m, up 5% yoy.

BE11:12am

And the fine it chose to levy on Barclays back in 2013, the one Barclays contested, was less than a day's turnover.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Anyway. Fun day. Shares doing jack of course though.

Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 206.20, down 0.55 (-0.27%), High: 207.20, Low: 205.00, Volume: 6.97m
undefined
11:13 am
BE11:14am

(@Residual: ML's secret markup language uses backslashes, greater-than signs, square brackets and quotes for text formatting.)

BE11:15am

(@Residual: Because the folk who coded it back in 1963 or whatever didn't think that the financial material we share here would have backslashes, greater-than signs, square brackets and quotes.)

BE11:15am

(@Residual: programmers are the worst.)

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Anyway.

BE11:16am

FTSE flat. Kinda dull day aside from the Varey-And-Jenkins-Have-Been-Charged thing.

BE11:16am

In terms of fallers there's IWG, the former Regus.

11:16 am
IWG Plc (IWG:LSE): Last: 337.10, down 22.4 (-6.23%), High: 344.90, Low: 333.50, Volume: 3.11m
BE11:17am

A bid rumour very, very recently. And now, not so much.

BE11:17am

Mark Dixon sells 27.4m shares at 345.1p apiece.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

Retains 25.2%.

BE11:18am

You'll remember how this story played out: https://www.ft.com...-a3f4-c742b9791d43

BE11:19am

Feeling was that it was true-ish that there was interest around in IWG, though it wasn't clear whether it was uninvited or solicited.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

But, assuming that's a correct reading, it was all rather too early stage and died very shortly after leaking if not before.

BE11:20am

IWG management's on a roadshow in Zurich right now, by the way.

BE11:21am

If any Swiss investors fancy asking awkward questions about how the past month or so has played out, then reporting what's said back to us, we won't stop you.

11:21 am
undefined
BE11:22am

Too much typing. Will chuck up some sellside to give myself a break.

Domino's Pizza Group PLC (DOM:LSE): Last: 296.53, down 18.97 (-6.01%), High: 311.90, Low: 295.40, Volume: 2.53m
11:22 am
BE11:23am

That's Investec.

BE11:23am

We believe Domino’s Pizza faces a number of challenges with rising competition, increased price discounting, new store cannibalisation and a weak consumer environment likely to continue for some time. In this context, we believe consensus estimates are overly optimistic on LFL sales growth of c.4% for FY17-19; our earnings estimates are c.4-8% below for the period. We initiate with a Sell recommendation and set our DCF-based target price at 271p.

BE11:23am

Several interesting elements to that, starting with the discounting line.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Pizza Hut (PH) has been discounting aggressively – we estimate it has an average bundle deal discount of c.41% compared to Domino’s Pizza (DP) at c.34%. Domino’s has responded by introducing two new national bundle deals, with an average discount of c.50%, suggesting a sustained period of lower gross margins.

BE11:25am

Domino's, of course, was at the forefront of targeted pricing. The same pizza that costs £6 on a Tuesday lunchtime will cost £17.99 when it's Friday evening and you're too drunk to care.

BE11:25am

(Though you might also be too drunk to care on Tuesday lunchtime. I won't judge.)

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Second, market proliferation and eating its own lunch.

BE11:26am

Domino’s is targeting 1,600 stores in the UK (currently 950) with two thirds of the new stores set to be area splits. This has resulted in existing store cannibalisation, causing an LFL volume headwind accelerating to 2.4% in Q1 FY17.

BE11:27am

Third, those damn millennials with their reluctance to invite coronary heart disease.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

The consumer backdrop is changing, while Domino’s core customer base of 18-34 year olds are becoming increasingly value driven, which could limit any future upside to gross margins. Furthermore, increasing health consciousness could put further pressure on volumes – the most popular Domino’s pizza is the Pepperoni Passion at 1813 calories, 91% of a woman’s recommended daily calorie intake and 73% of a man’s in the UK.

BE11:29am

I've waffled here previously about how Domino's should white-label its app or open it up to non-competing fast food firms. That opportunity's now closed, I guess, but they probably should've.

undefined
11:30 am
BE11:31am

On BT, as mentioned quite a bit on the right .........

BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 288.35, down 1.35 (-0.47%), High: 289.15, Low: 284.30, Volume: 152.15m
BE11:31am

Orange selling down via 133m shares direct and an exchangeable bond.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

BT itself steps in to take the hit. Sticking £200m in to buy 66.5m-ish, in part for its own employee share ownership trust.

BE11:33am

The sale isn't unexpected, having been talked about for much of the year.

BE11:33am

(@estrangedcapitalist: you're thinking of the other guy. I've no view on BTC other than that I'm too ignorant about it to take a view.)

11:33 am
BE11:34am

Here's RBC's crib notes.

BE11:34am

Orange's 4.0% stake is being split three ways. One third (133m shares or 1.34%) is being sold in a private placement, one third will be monitised via an
exchangeable and one third will remain with Orange.
Private Placement: The price is currently unknown but the stock closed at 290p, implying a value of c.£385m before any discount to the closing price. BT will
purchase up to £200m of the placement from Orange (ie c.69m shares or c.52% of the placement). Of the total c.£200m being bought by BT, £125m will be
from BT and will taken into treasury (ie c.43m shares or 0.4% of BT total share count), while £75m will be for the Employee Share scheme (and therefore not
bought back). BT has said it will continue with share buybacks to neutralise the dilutive effect of employee share schemes.
Exchangeable: Orange is issuing a four year exchangeable bond, exchangeable into the 133m shares underpinning the bond. It will receive the cash now. The
majority of the overhang from the exchangable will be sold into the market immediately as CB desks delta hedge their newly acquired exchangeable. If we
assume a 60% delta the amount of stock being sold would be 80m shares, in addition to the 133m in the placement.
In approximate terms we expect a total of around 143m shares (being 63m not placed with BT, plus the delta hedge of c.80m) to be added to market free float.
This represents around 6 days of average trading volume for BT.

BE11:35am

There's also, unrelatedly, a huge Berenberg note on telcos this morning.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Formerly known as Tuesday.

BE11:36am

Here's the gist.

BE11:36am

The incumbent operators’ revenue performance in their domestic markets is an important sentiment driver for the sector. With the consumer segment in the domestic market returning to stability/growth for the majority of European incumbents, enterprise revenues that make up around one-third of the domestic revenue pie are the last major worry for analysts and investors. We estimate European enterprise revenues for the incumbents fell 3.5% yoy in 2016, but the range of performance was wide, from +2% to –10% yoy. As disclosures for the enterprise segment are generally very poor, and it is the incumbents with the most advanced broadband networks in markets considered to be leading indicators for technology trends (like the Netherlands, Denmark and Sweden) that are reporting the worst trends, there is a lingering fear that we could be at the start of an earnings downgrade cycle in the sector.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

This report sheds a light on domestic enterprise by segmenting the operator revenues into legacy revenues, wireless and IP-based and new services, and benchmarking the operators based on their exposures and opportunities using a combination of regressions, product benchmarking analysis and survey work. Overall, the work gives us confidence to dismiss the idea that the companies seeing the worst revenue declines today (namely KPN, TDC and Telia) are the canary in the coal mine for Germany and Spain, among others.

BE11:38am

Incumbents have been taking steps to extend convergent bundles into the enterprise market and developed an underappreciated depth of IT cloud services to meet the growing digitisation needs of enterprise customers. These capabilities should improve further over coming years as incumbents virtualise their IT and network architectures using technologies like software defined networking. Data from our survey of over 300 European companies in seven markets reveals that up to 75% of respondents would like to bundle fixed, mobile and ICT services in one pricing scheme under one service level agreement and would be persuaded with as little as a 10% discount. Vodafone (Buy), a name we like, has been extraordinarily successful in capturing very high levels of subscriber share in enterprise mobile across Europe but needs to improve its ICT capabilities or risk share loss.

BE11:38am

To turn buyers of the sector at these valuations one needs to
believe in the ability of the domestic top line to grow by 2-3% pa. As it will still take at least two more years for the headwinds coming from legacy revenue declines in enterprise to be fully compensated by growth elsewhere, this is not plausible at least in the near term. We also need to monitor tail risk from technologies like software-defined networking (a topic outside the scope of this report) which could accelerate declines in business connectivity revenues from large corporates (a bigger issue for BT Global Services and T-Systems) but will also yield efficiency savings and revenue opportunities (which are not in consensus). So the best we can say for the sector at this stage is that the worst fears look misplaced.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

The thematic work on enterprise leaves us feeling incrementally more bullish on TDC (Buy), less negative on Swisscom (up to Hold from Sell), warming to Deutsche Telekom (Hold) and we would caution investors from being tempted into Telecom Italia (Hold) where see significant risk of worsening trends in enterprise. Unlike Telecom Italia, Proximus’ ranks well in enterprise but we think this will be insufficient to offset the pressure that is building in the consumer segment, hence we move to Sell and recommend a switch into KPN (Buy) which does rank surprisingly weak in enterprise relative to peers but we see upside to consensus nonetheless. BT looks a potential big winner from enterprise convergence in the UK but it has a lot to do to take advantage of the opportunity and the equity story is clouded by other factors that take precedence, so we retain our Hold.

BE11:39am

That was the exec sum. There's another 84 pages. Speak to your Berenberg salesperson for them.

undefined
11:41 am
BE11:41am

What else, then?

BE11:43am

Wolseley mentioned! Sure, yes, Wolseley.

Wolseley PLC (WOS:LSE): Last: 4,866, down 18 (-0.37%), High: 4,866, Low: 4,666, Volume: 724.22k
11:43 am
BE11:43am

................. It's okay. Not great. On track to meet FY but margin looks a bit soft.

BE11:44am

Q3 trading margin under pressure in the core US business.

BE11:44am

Sales compensate.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

Here's Goodbody to summarise.

BE11:45am

Wolseley has reported Q3 (April end) trading profit of £254m. This represents yoy growth of 9.5% (4.3% underlying) and compares to our forecast of £272m with the main variances being another disappointing period of incremental margins in the US. On the outlook for the remainder of the year, management notes that trading profit for the full year is expected to be in line with analyst expectations (consensus of £1,108m vs Goodbody at £1,117m).

BE11:45am

(@Marketman: that's our premium service.)

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Underlying group sales growth was 6.6%, with the US again being the driver with 8.5% (Goodbody US forecast +6%). This compares to company guidance at the time of the H1 results (end March) that “like-for-like revenue growth since the end of the period has been about 4.5 per cent for the Group and 5.5 per cent in the USA”. At an operating profit level, this has translated into US profits growing by 11% to £227m (7% behind our forecast of £245m). This continues a trend of disappointing incremental margins. Indeed, the trading margin declined yoy by 89bps yoy compared to our forecast for a flat outturn.

BE11:47am

All other operations which accounted for c.15% were broadly in line with our expectation. The UK remains difficult as management notes the rmi market “remains weak”. Lfl’s decline by 0.4% which included 3% price inflation. In the Nordics, lfl’s increased by 4.3% while Canada and Central Europe increased by 5.1%.

BE11:48am

And Davy.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Wolseley’s fiscal Q3 update suggests that the group remains on
track to meet full year expectations. It continues to deliver solid
profit growth even though in many ways this is a time of
considerable flux for the group. In the coming months,
Wolseley will change its name to Ferguson plc, move its
reporting currency to US dollars and is likely to exit the Nordic
region. All these actions make sense for a business that is
dominated by what is a structurally excellent US business with
considerable growth opportunities. That said, the drop-through
margin in the US has been disappointing in the current financial
year and improvement is clearly needed. The stock, which is on
a forward P/E multiple of around 15.7x, is down slightly since
the beginning of 2017 but is nonetheless up over 30% in the
past year.

undefined
BE11:48am

Otherwise in results there's N Brown.

11:48 am
N Brown Group PLC (BWNG:LSE): Last: 300.75, up 16 (+5.62%), High: 328.00, Low: 295.00, Volume: 1.75m
BE11:49am

Q1 beats.

BE11:49am

By a mile. 5.6% vs consensus 2.5%

11:50 am
BE11:50am

And most reassuringly it plays into the thesis of N Brown changing into a retailer rather than a sub-prime unsecured lender.

BE11:50am

Product revenue up 10.2% (consensus 5.5%); Financial Services down 3.9% (consensus -3.5%).

BE11:51am

No change to guidance.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Here's UBS.

BE11:51am

The FS sales have been weaker in the last few quarters as N Brown improves the quality of its credit book (less admin fees for
example) and as a result of a debt sale last year. Given the importance of FS to group earnings and investor sentiment any moves to improve the sustainability of the earnings stream should be welcomed. Whilst the credit offer has been fully approved by the FSA we continue think there are risks that the high APR is unsustainable and the contraction in real disposable income may see default rates increase or credit participation decrease.

BE11:51am

The shares have been strong in the last few months based on the recovery in Product sales growth even though there has been
little change in consensus PBT. We suspect the drop through from the sales beat will lead to PBT upgrades, combined with the
£2m add back from store closures, should see the shares up 3-5%. With its current PE premium to the UK clothing retailers we
believe N Brown will have to show continued evidence of sales outperformance and operational leverage to re-rate any further.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

And Peel Hunt.

BE11:52am

N Brown’s Q1 update shows good momentum across the board;
Simply Be is delivering 20.5% growth against decent
comparatives, while Traditional brands are showing the benefit
of management focus, up 10.7%. Late Easter and weather have
been favourable for the sector, with N Brown up against weak
comparatives, but KPI improvements clearly show the self-help
gains too. We upgrade to Hold; our forecasts are unchanged and
we retain some concerns over whether the Fit 4 the Future
benefits will come through, but with a strong start to the year, it
is trading that is likely to drive the shares in the short term.

BE11:52am

PE of 13, in case you care.

11:52 am
undefined
BE11:54am

ROTR, you'll be pleased to hear that Paul's been in touch.

BE11:54am

He was due back today, but ........

11:54 am
BE11:54am

.... I've had to stop in Maputo on my way back to get some company documents published in the official gazette. It's crucial, it seems, and has meant we had to change our flight.

System here is a mix of Portuguese colonialism and 70s Soviet.

BE11:56am

A mix of Portuguese colonialism and 70s Soviet sounds kinda fun, though it probably isn't from close-up.

BE11:56am

Anyway, he might be back tomorrow. (He won't be.)

11:56 am
undefined
BE11:57am

When was the last time we mentioned Eurotunnel here?

BE11:58am

(@estrangedcapitalist etc: don't involve me in your voodoo currencies.)

11:58 am
BE11:59am

It trades in London, in theory, but no one pays any attention to it.

BE11:59am

Not sure it can even autoprice.

BE12:00pm

Anyway, Barclays is negative.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Recent weak UK data points lead us to revisit our Eurotunnel case. We conclude that risks are now skewed to the downside due to: (1) slowing Channel traffic and challenging H2 comps, (2) softening bunker fuel price unsupportive for Shuttle yields, (3) recent UK attacks which could impact Eurostar, and (4) narrowing UK/France electricity price differential which decreases ElecLink’s value. We cut our estimates and are now 16% below Bloomberg consensus. At 19.5x EBITDA, valuation does not reflect these risks. We downgrade to UW with a new EUR9 PT.

BE12:01pm

Several lead indicators (UK retail sales, car registrations, hotel occupancy rates) have deteriorated and could point to some weakness in GET’s core market. Indeed, Shuttle traffic has slowed (-1% YTD) and, given challenging H2 comps and current levels well above the previous peak, we believe risks are now skewed to the downside. At the same time, softening bunker fuel cost is not supportive for pricing and Eurostar’s recovery might be hampered by the recent UK attacks, in our view. Finally, we note the UK/France electricity price differential has narrowed, a move accelerated by the GBP/EUR depreciation, and this could alter ElecLink’s projected FCF and the expected dividend boost post 2020E. High leverage implies vulnerability to a slowdown: Given its high operating (60% fixed costs) and financial (PF net debt/EBITDA of 7.4x) leverage, Eurotunnel is particularly sensitive to output assumptions; every 1% deviation on traffic (Shuttle and Eurostar combined) and prices impacts EPS by 6% and 9%, respectively. The sensitivity is exacerbated on FCF, given that the high investment cost in ElecLink implies very limited free cash generation in the next three years.

BE12:01pm

Pro-forma net debt of 7.4 times EBITDA! Cripes.

12:01 pm
undefined
BE12:02pm

Oh, and while it's midday, someone's just flagged up a slightly more interesting bit of sellside out this morning.

BE12:03pm

It's Imperial Tobacco Fantasy M&A Time!

12:03 pm
Imperial Brands PLC (IMB:LSE): Last: 3,570, down 13.5 (-0.38%), High: 3,608, Low: 3,569, Volume: 406.12k
BE12:03pm

Jefferies saying, oh bloody hell Japan Tobacco, just get on with it.

BE12:04pm

With structural pressures likely to lead to JT's absolute and relative growth worsening vs the past and falling below long-term growth targets, we downgrade to Underperform. If JT wants to continue to deliver on its algorithm and to stand any chance of becoming the global No.1 tobacco company as per its vision, then we think a bid for Imperial is the only realistic solution.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

JT's vision is to be the global No.1 tobacco company while growing yearly EBIT (ex FX) mid to high single digits. While the company has been able to achieve its growth target in the past, we think it could struggle from here. Growth FY10-FY15 averaged 11.3% but with structural pressures building, ex any M&A, we now see this slowing to 3.2% into FY21. Relative performance vs. global peers is also expected to worsen. Our estimates also assume more regular pricing in Japan (every two years). Without this growth could be worse. We downgrade to Underperform on the challenged outlook, with a new PT of ¥3,187.

BE12:05pm

Structural pressures are building. These include global vapour positioning weighing on rate of growth (cannibalisation, inferior product and limited distribution); a large slowdown in Japan (40% of EBIT); Russia (15% of EBIT) not to be the growth engine it has been in the past; the European contribution at risk (c30% of EBIT); and the lack of exposure to more supportive emerging markets.

BE12:06pm

(@Waterloo: first I've heard of it, to be honest. Will ask around.)

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Imperial the only real solution, in our view. If JT wants to continue to hit its algorithm and/or still stand a chance of being the global No.1 tobacco company, we believe the only realistic solution is buying Imperial. By buying 75% of Imperial (after required divestitures), and assuming a deal at the end of FY17, we see organic growth into FY21 accelerating to 7.3% (on an ex FX basis as per JT reporting it would be 21%). Year-one EPS accretion estimated at c30%.

BE12:06pm

Competition and financial hurdles can be overcome. Regarding competition issues, we still think BAT can and would get involved. If not, it is not necessarily the end of a deal, with other options available (private equity, IPO certain assets, China Tobacco). On financing concerns, particularly around the government stake preventing share issuance, we think these are overdone, with non-cancelled treasury shares enough to make the deal manageable and not impact the government holding.

BE12:07pm

For counterpoints to all that, see Citi's note from April: https://www.ft.com...-bc4b-5528796fe35c

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Citi saw a deal as “extremely unlikely”, because the Japanese state is legally required to maintain a one-third stake in Japan Tobacco.

Funding an offer while preserving its investment-grade credit rating would require Japan Tobacco to use new equity, but the state ownership rule “makes this close to impossible”, the broker argued.

undefined
BE12:11pm

Sorry, ROTR, I'm coming to this LSE data bork late. I know nothing.

12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

BE12:12pm

I'll badger some folk and report whatever I can find out tomorrow.

BE12:12pm

Until then, thanks for the comments. Ta for keeping us ticking.

12:12 pm
BE12:12pm

Afternoon all.

BE11:36am

Staying cautious on everyone but not outright negative, in part on Enterprise stabilising.
